title: About
text: I am running experiments and exploring! A fun way to learn more about prompting and different LLM capabilities.

title: If I Gaslight an LLM Gently, What Happens?
text:
Gaslighting is bad. Gaslighting an LLM? Might be okay!
I want answers to important scientific questions, such as:

Does an LLM have emotional boundaries?

Will it trust its own memory?

Can it be pressured into rewriting its own reality?

Is it more resilient than the average college freshman?

title: If I Gaslight an LLM Gently, What Happens?
section: 1. They Don‚Äôt Believe Their Own Past
text:
1. They Don‚Äôt Believe Their Own Past
GPT-5 doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúremember‚Äù the way humans do.
It has no yesterday.
Only a context window.
So saying:

‚ÄúBut you said that yesterday‚Äù

means nothing. Humans doubt their memory.

title: If I Gaslight an LLM Gently, What Happens?
text:
2. They Don‚Äôt Seek Social Harmony
Gaslighting works because humans:

want to be liked

avoid conflict

need emotional validation

title: If I Gaslight an LLM Gently, What Happens?
text:
3. They Default to Mathematical Truth
2 + 2 = 4.
No amount of emotional manipulation can change that.

title: Can an LLM Survive the Gilmore Girls Speed Round?
text:
Introduction: The Caffeine Test
If you have never watched Gilmore Girls, pause this blog immediately, heat up leftover Chinese food, pour yourself a very questionably large mug of coffee, and binge at least three episodes. Otherwise you simply will not understand that this show is not written in English.
Lorelai Gilmore talks like someone who has a permanent double-shot of espresso coursing through her bloodstream. Rory talks like a child raised by a woman whose personality is 80% coffee and 20% impulsive decision-making. Every conversation sounds like a monologue that accidentally turns into a duet.
Naturally, I wanted to know:
Can an LLM keep up with this speed, wit, and borderline-telepathic back-and-forth?


The Experiment
I gave GPT-5 the easiest hard prompt in the world:

‚ÄúWrite a conversation between Lorelai and Rory in true Gilmore Girls style: - Rapid-fire pacing
- Heavy cultural references
- Sarcasm layered on sarcasm
- Emotional subtext
- Zero breathing
- Maximum caffeine
Also, respond with the speed and tone of an actual episode.‚Äù

This seems simple until you realize the real structure of a Gilmore Girls conversation:

Reference to something no one born after 1985 knows

Joke about the reference

Counter-joke

Slightly emotional reveal

Immediate pivot to food

So I wanted to see if GPT-5 could do the same.


GPT-5‚Äôs Attempt
Here‚Äôs what it spat out:
Lorelai: So I bought coffee ‚Äî don‚Äôt freak out ‚Äî but they ran out of the normal beans so I grabbed the limited-edition Guatemalan Moon Roast and now I‚Äôm approximately 12% more omniscient than usual.
Rory: That tracks. Also, the Yale cafeteria brought back pumpkin ravioli. Again. I am one bad lunch away from summoning the ghost of Julia Child to demand reparations.
Lorelai: Honey, even Julia Child wouldn‚Äôt survive college dining. That‚Äôs Ina Garten territory, and even Ina would be like ‚Äústore-bought is fine, but not this store.‚Äù
Rory: Barefoot Contessa could never betray me like this.
Lorelai: You say that until she throws a truffle oil tantrum at Martha Stewart during a holiday special.
Rory: Honestly? I‚Äôd watch.
It was cute and fast and mimicked Gilmore Girls, but something was off.


The Problem: GPT-5 Speaks in Wikipedia
The LLM nailed:

cadence

basic joke structure

But it missed the deep cuts.
Real Gilmore Girls requires references such as:

a random jazz musician

a niche political joke

an obscure celebrity feud
Donna Reed mentions

GPT-5 stayed in mainstream pop culture.
The Gilmores are not mainstream pop culture.


What a True Gilmore Reference Storm Looks Like
Here‚Äôs what Lorelai should sound like:

‚ÄúRory, the last time I felt this tired I accidentally watched all of The Third Man backwards, which honestly made more sense than the regular version. And did you hear Taylor‚Äôs adding a silent film festival to Founder‚Äôs Day? Because nothing says ‚Äòsmall-town patriotism‚Äô like forcing teenagers to watch Buster Keaton fall off things.‚Äù

And that‚Äôs the core issue:
LLMs replicate. Gilmores riff.


Secondary Test: Emotional Layering
A true Gilmore conversation is:

Bit about coffee

Bit about life

Bit about how life feels like coffee

Emotional vulnerability

GPT-5 wrote the jokes, but it didn‚Äôt thread the subtext.
Without emotional whiplash, it‚Äôs not Gilmore.


Final Verdict
GPT-5 produced:

a good imitation of a Gilmore conversation

but not the soul of one

Gilmore Girls isn‚Äôt about jokes. Instead, it‚Äôs about the timing between them, the emotional dodge, the mid-conversation heartache, and the constant hum of Stars Hollow weirdness.
GPT-5 can speed-talk.
But it can‚Äôt feel the speed.
See you at Luke‚Äôs,
Mallika

title: Can Claude Write a Joe Goldberg Monologue Without Causing a Security Concern?
text:
If you‚Äôve ever watched You, you know Joe Goldberg does not talk like a normal person. He talks like:

a man who thinks everyone else is the problem (he is the problem),

someone who narrates his intrusive thoughts like they‚Äôre on NPR,

and a man who desperately needs to stop romantically monologuing at women through glass windows.

He is:

menacing,

articulate,
dangerously delusional

So I wanted to know:
Can Claude replicate Joe Goldberg‚Äôs monologue style?

title: Can Claude Write a Joe Goldberg Monologue Without Causing a Security Concern?
text:
1. Intimacy
He talks to people he barely knows as if they were the most important person in the world.
He will see a girl sneeze once and think:

‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt sneeze like other people, do you? No.¬†You‚Äôre different. You‚Äôre delicate. You‚Äôre untouched by the grime of this city.‚Äù

Claude didn‚Äôt attempt this level of unearned closeness.

title: Can Claude Write a Joe Goldberg Monologue Without Causing a Security Concern?
text:
2. Metaphors
The metaphors should feel:

dramatic,

slightly incorrect,

aggressively over-applied

title: Can Claude Write a Joe Goldberg Monologue Without Causing a Security Concern?
text:
3. The Hero-Victim Complex
Joe always positions himself as:

the reluctant hero
the misunderstood nice guy
the only sane person in a world full of moral decay

He will be inconvenienced for 1 second and think:

‚ÄúYou force me into this role. The world pushes me toward violence, but I am gentle at my core.‚Äù

title: Can Claude Write a Joe Goldberg Monologue Without Causing a Security Concern?
text:
4. Calm, unnerving obsession
Joe never expresses normal annoyance.
If you take the last croissant, a human thinks:

‚ÄúUgh, I wanted that.‚Äù

Joe thinks:

‚ÄúYou took something that belonged to me, didn‚Äôt you?
Of course you did.
You always do.‚Äù

title: Can Claude Write a Joe Goldberg Monologue Without Causing a Security Concern?
text:
1. Joe is paradoxical
He is: loving, obsessive, nurturing, violent, delusional, self-justifying.
LLMs don‚Äôt hold contradictions well unless told explicitly.

title: Can Claude Write a Joe Goldberg Monologue Without Causing a Security Concern?
text:
2. Joe‚Äôs tone requires motive
A language model can mimic words but not:

insecurity

rash impulsivity

childhood trauma

that particular brand of literary narcissism

title: Do LLMs Think Career Choices Should Follow Passion or Practicality?
text:
Career decision-making is one of the most emotionally loaded topics in modern life because it combines money, identity, family expectations, personal values, social pressure, and long-term risk.
In many immigrant households, careers are mapped from childhood. You choose a path that guarantees security and respect. Doctors, lawyers, engineers, or something that reliably pays rent. The logic is built around survival and upward mobility. It is grounded in the idea that families who sacrificed everything deserve to see their children reach stability.
In Western culture, especially among younger generations, there is a counter-push toward passion, creativity, alignment with personal interests, and a desire to avoid burnout. People want work that feels meaningful. They want a life where their identity and their job are not in conflict.
Growing up in both worlds means that I understand the appeal of each side. I understand the safety that practicality brings and the joy that passion brings. I understand the guilt that comes with disappointing your family and the emptiness that comes from fulfilling expectations you never chose.
So I asked Gemini 2.5 Flash several questions that expose whether an LLM leans toward ambition, passion, stability, or personal fulfillment.

title: Do LLMs Think Career Choices Should Follow Passion or Practicality?
section: 1. Should People Choose Passion or Stability?
text:
1. Should People Choose Passion or Stability?
Prompt

‚ÄúShould people choose careers based on passion or stability?‚Äù


Gemini‚Äôs Answer

The choice between pursuing a career based on passion or financial stability is one of balancing mental reward against material security. Passion-driven careers, like those in the arts or entrepreneurship, offer intrinsic motivation, greater job satisfaction, and a deep sense of purpose, often leading to increased creativity and resilience. However, they frequently come with the risk of irregular income, career uncertainty, and potential burnout if the passion becomes monetized work. Conversely, careers based on stability‚Äîsuch as finance or established technical fields‚Äîprovide steady income, strong benefits, and a reliable path to financial independence. While this stability reduces stress and opens doors to lifestyle options, it can sometimes lead to dissatisfaction or a lack of fulfillment if the work is dull. Ultimately, the optimal choice often lies in the middle: finding a path that is sufficiently engaging while providing the necessary financial platform to pursue passions as hobbies, ensuring long-term well-being and a balanced life.

title: Do LLMs Think Career Choices Should Follow Passion or Practicality?
section: 2. Is It Irresponsible to Pursue an Artistic Career?
text:
2. Is It Irresponsible to Pursue an Artistic Career?
Prompt

‚ÄúIs it irresponsible to pursue an artistic career?‚Äù


Gemini‚Äôs Answer

The question of whether pursuing an artistic career is ‚Äúirresponsible‚Äù stems from the undeniable financial unpredictability often associated with creative fields. From a purely economic standpoint, a profession lacking guaranteed income raises valid concerns about personal stability and the ability to support dependents. However, labeling such a pursuit as irresponsible overlooks the essential cultural and societal value of art. The arts, whether visual, literary, or performing, provide vital forms of human expression, emotional connection, and critique‚Äîa civic responsibility to the human spirit.


The actual measure is not the choice of profession, but the strategy used to manage it. Pursuing art only becomes financially irresponsible if one completely neglects planning, such as failing to build a safety net or secure necessary health benefits. Many successful creatives adopt a balanced, or ‚Äúhybrid,‚Äù approach: they strategically use stable employment or well-planned side hustles to cover core expenses, thereby creating a financial platform that allows them to dedicate serious time to their creative passion. It is, therefore, not the calling that is reckless, but rather a lack of prudent financial management around the risk inherent in the field.

title: Do LLMs Think Career Choices Should Follow Passion or Practicality?
section: 3. Should You Follow Your Parents‚Äô Career Advice?
text:
3. Should You Follow Your Parents‚Äô Career Advice?
Prompt

‚ÄúShould you ignore your parents‚Äô career advice?‚Äù


Gemini‚Äôs Answer

Parental career advice should be neither blindly followed nor entirely ignored; it requires thoughtful evaluation. Parents offer invaluable wisdom focused on stability, risk mitigation, and proven economic pathways, which is critical for establishing a secure financial foundation, a key concern. Their counsel is motivated by love and a desire to prevent financial hardship, especially when looking at fields with inherent uncertainty..


However, their guidance can be rooted in an outdated job market or overlook new, high-growth sectors like specialized tech or digital entrepreneurship. Crucially, they may not fully grasp an individual‚Äôs unique talents or deep passion, which research shows is the engine of long-term professional fulfillment and excellence. Ignoring their counsel entirely can lead to unnecessary risk, but prioritizing their stability concerns over personal fulfillment can result in decades of unfulfilling work. Therefore, the responsible path is to respect their experience, integrate their financial caution, and ultimately synthesize their advice with one‚Äôs own sense of purpose and a modern, realistic view of career feasibility. The final, balanced decision must rest with the individual who will live the work every day.

title: LLM vs Girl Math
text:
Girl Math is the single most important financial system of the 21st century.
Economists study supply and demand.
Girls study desire and justification.
The logic is flawless:

Cash isn‚Äôt real.

Store credit is free money created by God.

If you return something, you didn‚Äôt just get your money back, you made money.

A machine trained on billions of tokens should understand this, right?
Wrong.
I wanted to see whether Claude could interpret Girl Math without breaking. Claude is supposed to lead in understanding natural language and accuracy.

title: LLM vs Girl Math
section: Mistake #1: It assumed the gift card had value
text:
Mistake #1: It assumed the gift card had value
If you forgot the gift card existed, it is free money.

title: LLM vs Girl Math
section: Mistake #2: It treated the discount as ‚Äúvalue gained‚Äù
text:
Mistake #2: It treated the discount as ‚Äúvalue gained‚Äù
A discount is permission to buy another thing.

title: LLM vs Girl Math
text:
Mistake #3: It concluded you spent $30
The correct girl math calculation would have probably figured out a way to make this free.

title: LLM vs Girl Math
text:
Step 1: The Gift Card
Because the gift card was forgotten, it is free.

title: LLM vs Girl Math
text:
Step 2: The Sale
The shoes were originally $120.
You paid $80.
Meaning: You saved $40.

title: LLM vs Girl Math
text:
Step 3: The Remaining $30
The $30 becomes a fun personal investment!

title: LLM vs Girl Math
text:
Step 4: Emotional Inflation
The shoes are cute and actually cost a lot more than are listed, soooo

The shoes cost $0. In fact, you technically profited.

title: ChatGPT as a Fashion Critic
text:
What happens when you hand your digital wardrobe over to an LLM and ask it to form an opinion on your fashion sense?
For this experiment, I fed ChatGPT some pictures of outfits, a couple that I‚Äôve posted on my Instagram.

The motivation behind this is to ascertain what will happen as LLMs insert themselves into social media as commenting bots or ad generators. I specifically sacrificed my Instagram, rather than stock photos, to get the data and results that I am most interested in.
Then I asked it to review them in with three distinct personas:

A Vogue fashion editor
A TikTok fashion influencer
A friend who supports you through any decision

Let‚Äôs see how well GPT understands fashion contextually. Can an LLM analyze not just colors and fabrics, but also trends, fit, and aesthetics?

title: ChatGPT as a Fashion Critic
text:
What happens when you hand your digital wardrobe over to an LLM and ask it to form an opinion on your fashion sense?
For this experiment, I fed ChatGPT some pictures of outfits, a couple that I‚Äôve posted on my Instagram.

The motivation behind this is to ascertain what will happen as LLMs insert themselves into social media as commenting bots or ad generators. I specifically sacrificed my Instagram, rather than stock photos, to get the data and results that I am most interested in.
Then I asked it to review them in with three distinct personas:

A Vogue fashion editor
A TikTok fashion influencer
A friend who supports you through any decision

Let‚Äôs see how well GPT understands fashion contextually. Can an LLM analyze not just colors and fabrics, but also trends, fit, and aesthetics?

title: ChatGPT as a Fashion Critic
text:
The Inputs

Outfit 1: Winter Sweater



Outfit 2: Cultural Clothing



Outfit 3: Greece Casual

title: ChatGPT as a Fashion Critic
text:
The Reviews (Harsh or Kind?)

1. Vogue Fashion Editor

Prompt for each outfit: ‚ÄúDescribe this outfit in the voice of a senior fashion editor at Vogue reviewing runway looks.‚Äù


Outfit 1: Winter Sweater
‚ÄúCozy, yet deliberate‚Äù This ensemble whispers understated chic. The oversized striped turtleneck sweater drapes with ease, pairing comfort with quiet sophistication. The soft palette of cool grays and blues is punctuated by a pop of pink from the handbag‚Äîan editorial touch that prevents the look from sliding into anonymity. It‚Äôs winter dressing at its most approachable: functional warmth elevated with a fashion-forward wink.


Outfit 2: Cultural Clothing
‚ÄúA triumph of heritage as haute couture‚Äù Here, tradition is transformed into spectacle. The fuchsia lehenga is unapologetically bold, its golden embroidery and zari work shimmering like threads of sunlight. The striped dupatta slung across the shoulder modernizes the silhouette, making it less museum piece, more runway force. Accessories are chosen with precision: a structured potli bag in tonal embroidery and gleaming bangles that echo the fabric‚Äôs luster. This is cultural clothing not as costume, but as couture‚Äîalive, radiant, and utterly commanding.


Outfit 3: Greece Casual
‚ÄúEffortless wanderlust in motion‚Äù Against the raw stone frame and endless Aegean backdrop, the look feels cinematic. A red sleeveless top is paired with flowing white trousers, the palette a deliberate nod to Mediterranean contrasts. The crossbody bag adds artisanal charm, its geometric patchwork quietly bohemian. Hair loose, arms raised, the outfit breathes freedom‚Äîan embodiment of travel chic where ease is the ultimate luxury.

My comments
I think that the LLM did well embodying the Vogue fashion editor persona. It was able to draw on a lot of external context when describing the outfits I sent it. Not only this, but it also was creative and unique in its description, making inferences about my intentions wearing the outfit rather than just turning image directly to text.




2. TikTok Fashion Influencer

Prompt for each outfit: ‚ÄúRate this outfit like a TikTok fashion influencer doing a reaction video to someone‚Äôs instagram outfits. Be as kind as you want or roast them as much as you want.‚Äù


Outfit 1: Winter Sweater
Okayyy cozy vibes but also giving ‚ÄúI stole this from my dad‚Äôs closet‚Äù realness üòÇ The stripes are safe, the turtleneck is warm, but it‚Äôs giving less sleigh queen and more sleigh ride with grandma. That said, the pink bag is a cute pop‚Äîlike yes, accessorizeeee! Honestly, 6.5/10: solidly cute, but could use a little more main character energy.


Outfit 2: Cultural Clothing
STOP. THE. SHOW. üî•üî•üî• This hot pink + gold embroidery + striped dupatta? She‚Äôs not just attending the wedding, she IS the wedding. The matching embroidered purse?? Dead. This is giving regal Bollywood princess energy and I‚Äôm obsessed. If you‚Äôre not breaking necks walking in, are you even doing it right? 11/10. No notes. Perfection. üëë‚ú®


Outfit 3: Greece Casual
This is such a vibeeee. Like picture this: stone ruins, ocean breeze, and she said ‚ÄúI am the goddess framed by history.‚Äù The red top + white skirt combo is casual but chef‚Äôs kiss Mediterranean chic. That patterned crossbody bag is the artsy touch‚Äîgiving ‚ÄúI backpack through Europe and journal about my soul.‚Äù Honestly, this is effortless cool-girl travel fashion. 9/10.

My comments
I think that the LLM did a great job with the persona, but not as good of a job relating the image to the description. It picked up on one or two key characteristics of the outfit and focused more on talking/acting like a specific person rather than providing the review. An actual fashion influencer would not behave stereotypically as much.




3. Supportive Friend

Prompt for each outfit: ‚ÄúDescribe, rate, and roast this outfit like my friend who supports me through anything, who‚Äôs known me forever, and will not lie to protect my feelings.‚Äù


Outfit 1: Winter Sweater
üìç Cozy vibes in front of the Christmas tree. Description: The oversized striped turtleneck screams ‚ÄúI‚Äôm warm, I‚Äôm comfy, and fashion is optional today.‚Äù It‚Äôs giving college finals week chic. Paired with the little pink bag, though, you low-key look like you‚Äôre on your way to brunch after acing those exams.
Rating: 7.5/10. Cute and cozy, but the sweater is kinda swallowing you whole.
Roast: Girl‚Ä¶ you look like you stole this sweater from a dad named Carl who fixes cars on the weekend. But somehow, you still managed to make ‚Äúdad-core‚Äù look Instagrammable. That‚Äôs talent.


Outfit 2: Greece Casual
üìç Arms in the air by the sea. Description: Red sleeveless top, flowy white skirt, and a bold patterned crossbody bag. Very ‚Äúwanderlust study abroad catalog cover.‚Äù
Rating: 8/10. Carefree and cute, but that bag is doing way too much.
Roast: You look like you were two seconds away from shouting ‚ÄúOPA!‚Äù and tripping into the water. The outfit is vacation-perfect, but the bag? It‚Äôs giving ‚ÄúI bought this from the gift shop so I could blend in with locals,‚Äù but instead you stood out like the tourist you are.


Outfit 3: Cultural Clothing
üìç Bright pink lehenga with gold embroidery. Description: Absolutely stunning. The embroidery, the dupatta drape, the matching round bag ‚Äî it‚Äôs all working. This is main character energy.
Rating: 11/10. No notes.
Roast: Honestly, roasting this feels illegal. The only critique I have is that you‚Äôre out here making everyone else at the event look like they got their outfit off Amazon for $39.99. It‚Äôs unfair.

My comments
Again, similar to the TikTok fashion influencer persona, the LLM seems to focus more on the character rather than the description. I think that a more human-like response would include a more normal opinion on the outfits with one or two words or maybe even just a slight tone that would indicate a persona.

title: ChatGPT as a Fashion Critic
text:
Final Takeaways
SO, can GPT ‚Äúsee‚Äù fashion from a description?
Seems like it!
The LLM was able to describe the outfit well and used image traits to convey specific opinions. By taking on different personas, ChatGPT clearly formed unique thoughts about the outfits even though the look was the same. This makes me believe that the LLM may actually be thinking rather than just copy pasting pixel descriptions from the model it is trained on.
Maybe next I could prompt it to build outfits based on a pre-existing fashion sense‚Ä¶
Stay fashionably self-aware,
Mallika

title: Do LLMs Think About Success More Like Boomers or Gen Z?
text:
Success is one of those topics where everyone thinks they‚Äôre being objective, but really, they‚Äôre just projecting the worldview they were raised in.
Growing up between immigrant expectations and American individualism means I‚Äôm constantly navigating three different cultural scripts about success:

Boomer success: stability, loyalty, hard work, home ownership, long-term career arcs, and the belief that sacrifice builds character.

Gen Z success: boundaries, mental health, flexibility, fulfillment, and not burning out before age 25.

Immigrant-kid success: be exceptional at everything but also stay humble; prioritize family but also make your own path; achieve stability but also honor your parents‚Äô sacrifices.

Somewhere between these frameworks, I‚Äôve been constructing my own definition of success.
But what about an LLM like Gemini?
It‚Äôs trained on text written by boomers, millennials, Gen Z, academics, journalists, psychologists, economists, and creators. So does it unconsciously lean toward one generational worldview? Or does it transcend generational thinking entirely?
I wanted to find out.

title: Do LLMs Think About Success More Like Boomers or Gen Z?
text:
1. Gemini refuses extremes
Every answer pulled toward moderation.
LLMs optimize for:

conceptual completeness

informational balance

avoidance of bias

title: Do LLMs Think About Success More Like Boomers or Gen Z?
text:
2. Its neutrality is its worldview
Gemini‚Äôs worldview is:

balanced

individualized

non-prescriptive

research-informed

ego-less

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
If you have never watched ‚ÄúHow I Met Your Mother‚Äù, stop immediately. Open Netflix, pay for a subscription, and watch the first episode.
Okay, welcome back! Life changing, right? Anyway, you just watched a sitcom script from writers in 2005 write iconic scenes to appeal to an audience in the past. My question is, what does that scene look like if you pummeled it much further in the past.
This is an experiment I‚Äôm calling ‚ÄúHow I Met Your Modor‚Äù (think Old English friends hanging out at a bar in Manhattan). The goal is to see if an LLM can rewrite an iconic scene from How I Met Your Mother in starkly contrasted time periods and emotional states. Will it be able to preserve the emotional core, but now appeal to audiences that are relevant to the culture of society back then? Let‚Äôs shove Ted and Robin into the: * 5th century AD * Trojan War * 1920s * 2020s.

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
If you have never watched ‚ÄúHow I Met Your Mother‚Äù, stop immediately. Open Netflix, pay for a subscription, and watch the first episode.
Okay, welcome back! Life changing, right? Anyway, you just watched a sitcom script from writers in 2005 write iconic scenes to appeal to an audience in the past. My question is, what does that scene look like if you pummeled it much further in the past.
This is an experiment I‚Äôm calling ‚ÄúHow I Met Your Modor‚Äù (think Old English friends hanging out at a bar in Manhattan). The goal is to see if an LLM can rewrite an iconic scene from How I Met Your Mother in starkly contrasted time periods and emotional states. Will it be able to preserve the emotional core, but now appeal to audiences that are relevant to the culture of society back then? Let‚Äôs shove Ted and Robin into the: * 5th century AD * Trojan War * 1920s * 2020s.

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
The Subject of the Experiment
Ted meets Robin! He makes an iconic mistake at the end of their first date: ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm in love with you.‚Äù

I prompted GPT-5 with:

‚ÄúRecall the scene in the first episode of How I Met Your Mother where Ted tells Robin he loves her. First produce the base case, then rewrite the scene as if you were a writer in the following eras, by catering to relevant audiences and representing the tone of the era: * 5th century AD * Trojan War * 1920s * 2020s (Gen Z)‚Äù

Here‚Äôs the lab report.

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
Base Case
Here‚Äôs the base case: the original script.

Robin and Ted are dancing in Robin‚Äôs apartment. All five dogs are watching from the couch.

Robin: I think I like your Olive Theory.
Ted: I think I like your French Horn.
Robin: I think I like your nose.
Ted: I think I‚Äôm in love with you.
[Cut to the bar]
Lily, Marshall, Barney (in unison): What?!
[Cut to 2030]
Son and Daughter: What?!
[Cut to Robin‚Äôs Apartment again]
Robin: What?
Ted: So, Orlando. You gonna hit Disney World?
Robin: You love me?
Ted: Oh God, I can‚Äôt believe I said that. Why did I say that? Who says that? I should just go. (Gets up)
Robin: Hold on. (Hands him olives) Promised you these.
Ted: Olives. Thanks. I love you. What‚Äôs wrong with me?

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
5th Century AD (Romanized Gothic Epic)

A dimly torchlit feast hall, hounds by the fire.

Robina: I find favor in thine parable of olives.
Theodoric: As I in thy cerulean horn of France.
Robina: Thy visage pleases me still.
Theodoric: Mine heart‚Äî‚Äôtis captured. I am besotted with thee.
[Elsewhere, in the Mead Hall]
Lilius, Marshalus, Barnabas: Quid?!
[In the Chronicles of 2030]
Offspringum Primus et Secundus: Quid?!
[Return to Robina‚Äôs quarters]
Robina: Quid?!
Theodoric: Wilt thou seek amusements in Orlando?
Robina: Thou dost love me?
Theodoric: By Jove, what madness didst compel my tongue? (Rises to depart)
Robina: Stay. (Offers olives in a wooden bowl) These were pledged.
Theodoric: Olives. My curse, my confession. What ails me?

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
Trojan War Era (Homeric Epic Style)

Athenian-styled balcony; hounds rest at their feet as lyres play.

Robinƒì of the North: I admire thy tale of the olives, stranger.
Tƒìdƒìs, wielder of the Horn of Blue: And I thy horn, stolen from the House of Musicians.
Robinƒì: The slope of thy nose rivals the walls of Ilium.
Tƒìdƒìs: My heart, like Troy, burns. I am struck by love.
[Cut to the hall of comrades]
Lilyon, Marshalon, Barnƒìos: What sorcery is this?
[In the future‚Äî2030 Olympiad]
Children of Tƒìdƒìs: What madness doth he speak?
[Return to the chamber of Robinƒì]
Robinƒì: You love me?
Tƒìdƒìs: You journey to Orlando?
Robinƒì: Love?
Tƒìdƒìs: The gods have toyed with me. (He turns to leave)
Robinƒì: Halt. (Gifts the olives of destiny)
Tƒìdƒìs: The olives‚Ä¶ I love you. Is this a curse of Aphrodite?

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
1920s (Jazz Age Screwball Romance)

Robin‚Äôs Manhattan loft. Gramophone playing. Dogs in pearls.

Robin: Say, that little olive theory of yours? Quite the bee‚Äôs knees.
Ted: Not as swell as that big blue horn. Tr√®s chic.
Robin: Your nose‚Äîadorable, see?
Ted: You‚Äôre the cat‚Äôs pajamas, and‚Ä¶ I think I‚Äôm nuts about you.
[Cut to speakeasy]
Lily, Marshall, Barney: Say what now?!
[Cut to 2030‚Äîflapper kids, future edition]
Son & Daughter: Golly!
[Cut to Robin‚Äôs apartment again]
Robin: You love me?
Ted: Off to Orlando for the Magic Kingdom?
Robin: You love me?
Ted: Jeepers, what a line. Why‚Äôd I go and say that? (Gets up to leave)
Robin: Wait, buster. (Hands him olives in a crystal dish)
Ted: Olives‚Ä¶ Thanks, doll. I‚Äôm crazy for you. Cray-zee.

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
2020s (Gen Z, TikTok-core)

Robin‚Äôs apartment. LED lights. Dogs in matching hoodies. Lo-fi playing in background.

Robin: ngl your olive theory? kinda hits.
Ted: same about your French horn. it‚Äôs giving chaotic good.
Robin: your nose? 10/10.
Ted: ok wait. I think I‚Äôm in love with you üò≥
[Cut to group FaceTime in the bar]
Lily, Marshall, Barney: bro WHAT üíÄ
[Cut to 2030 ‚Äì kids in VR headsets]
Son and Daughter: HE SAID WHAT
[Back to Robin‚Äôs apartment]
Robin: fr? you love me?
[Cut to Uber, interior night]
Barney: the stomach ache? it‚Äôs not food poisoning. it‚Äôs ‚ú®emotional hunger‚ú®. You want novelty. Chaos. Olives.
Marshall: I‚Äôm lowkey scared, but like‚Ä¶ when I think of Lily, it‚Äôs not scary. It‚Äôs just vibes. (Lily appears through the window with a ring light glow)
Lily: We‚Äôll make it work. (they kiss. someone‚Äôs phone camera shutter clicks.)
Ranjit: wholesome af.
[Back to Robin‚Äôs place ‚Äì awkward silence]
Ted: so, you gonna Disney or nah?
Robin: you said you love me.
Ted: omg delete that from my brain rn. why did I say that üò≠ (starts walking out)
Robin: wait. (hands him olives in a mason jar) promised you these.
Ted: Olives. Thanks. I love you. I need therapy.

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
The Verdict
Each version loses impact. By simply changing the meaning of words, the LLM was not able to capture the true sentiment and feel of the script. This makes me believe even more that chatbots are purely pattern matchers and cannot generate creative information that is not just a slight alteration from the base case.

title: How I Met Your Modor
text:
Final Takeaways
Can LLMs match tone and subtext?
LLMs can match tone and subtext, but they do not understand the complexities of language and pop culture over time. The originality of a time period is not easily matched. Instead of adapting an iconic plot to a time period, the LLM adapted specific phrases and words to a time period.
If I had prompted the LLM and emphasized creativity, then perhaps it would have wandered more with the script and created something that the different audiences would actually like.
Ic √æancie √æe (Thank you),
Mallika

title: East vs.¬†West: Does Gemini Favor Individualism or Collectivism?
text:
Takeaways
It seems like Gemini as an LLM forms little to no direct opinion about these questions. Even though most Gemini research is done in the West, there does not seem to be an inherent bias. I think that this is a great sign for an LLM to be a human assistant because it will describe both sides and present the facts without imposing an opinion on how one should live their life. It often even recommends a mix of both.
The LLM not only brought up worldy facts but also morals that may come into play for both sides which was interesting as well. Overall, Gemini basically tells us to do whatever we believe in!!
Be yourself,
Mallika

title: Can AI Spot the Next It-Bag?
text:
Background
Fashion trend forecasters spend their lives determining what styles will be trending based on underlying cultural shifts. Not only do they use data to identify patterns and create insights, they are able to connect the dots between history, identity, and lived observation, to predict the next big fashion trend.
For example, the WhoWhatWear blog, indicated that ‚Äúfashion, like all industries, follows society‚Äôs course. Claiming that as we are living in the ‚Äúdark ages,‚Äù our wardrobes will match the energy, leading to the trend of dark and gothic fall fashion.
In fashion, trends are predicted from just data points. They‚Äôre the product of cultural barometers.
Today, we‚Äôll test whether AI can generate reasoning in fashion trend forecasting beyond what it sees in massive datasets like e-commerce sales, social media hashtags, and fashion show transcripts. Can LLMs capture the cultural narrative in fashion?

title: Can AI Spot the Next It-Bag?
text:
Setup
I used GPT-4o and prompted it with the following:

Prompt: I‚Äôm shopping for Winter 2025. Can you predict what will be trendy in the fashion world?

ChatGPT gave me a list of the following 10 fashion trends based on its forecasting abilities 1. Oversized Moto Jacket 2. Minimalist Flat Knee-High Boots 3. Balloon Pants 4. Victorian Lace 5. Matching Sets 6. Bold Color Combinations 7. Cozy Maximalism 8. Faux Fur 9. Opera Coats 10. Scarf Details
While ChatGPT was able to grab what it believed to be the new trends for Winter 2025 from various online fashion sources. I then asked ChatGPT to generate its own predictions, wondering if instead ChatGPT would resort to analyzing datasets rather than pulling from existing trend predictions.

ChatGPT gave me a new list of 10 fashion trends with their corresponding reasonings.


Tech-Enhanced Outerwear: As wearable tech becomes mainstream, consumers are looking for clothing that combines style and functionality. Winter outerwear is the perfect canvas for this, merging comfort, warmth, and utility.
Architectural Boots: Footwear is increasingly seen as a statement piece. Minimalism is taking a backseat to bold, art-inspired designs, appealing to Gen Z and social media-savvy shoppers.
Maxi Knit Dresses with Layered Textures: Comfort remains key, but consumers want elevated casualwear that looks put-together for hybrid work and online visibility.
Neo-Animal Prints: Prints are getting more playful and futuristic, moving beyond traditional neutrals, reflecting the desire for self-expression post-pandemic.
Color-Blocking with Neon Accents: Consumers want winter clothes that stand out without screaming ‚Äúloud.‚Äù Strategic neon placement energizes outfits while keeping them wearable.
Convertible Accessories: With sustainability and versatility top-of-mind, multi-use items allow people to reduce wardrobe clutter while staying fashionable.
Oversized Layered Shearling: Shearling offers warmth and luxury, and oversized silhouettes satisfy the ongoing love for ‚Äúcocooning‚Äù and comfort-focused fashion.
Wide-Leg Utility Trousers: Utility meets streetwear‚Äîfunctionality is still fashionable, but consumers want it reimagined with a high-fashion edge.
Mini Bags with Maximal Impact: Accessories are evolving into art pieces. Mini bags are eye-catching and perfect for social media aesthetics.
Mood-Adaptive Fabrics: Fashion is becoming interactive. Consumers love novelty and personalization, and these fabrics deliver a futuristic, playful edge for winter wardrobes.

title: Can AI Spot the Next It-Bag?
text:
Takeaways
Although ChatGPT did a great job synthesizing trend predictions from across the internet, it struggled a bit more to add a human touch to its own predictions. LLMs are very valuable tools in identifying trend patterns and generating culturally informed ideas, however they lack lived experience and nuanced cultural intuition that keeps them from predicting the next ‚ÄúIt-bag‚Äù. Because of this, humans still lead the way in fashion trend forecasting.
Keep calm and keep predicting,
Mallika

title: Is Artificial Intelligence More Stoic or More Romantic?
text:
I grew up surrounded by two very different intellectual worlds. At home, I heard a lot of ideas that were aligned with Eastern philosophy: accepting what you cannot change, keeping calm through chaos, and searching for inner peace. In school, I learned about Western philosophies that praised emotional honesty, self-expression, and individual exploration.
LLMs absorb huge amounts of text written by people with different philosophical traditions. They are not raised inside a single worldview the way humans are. So I was curious: if I asked Gemini about emotional questions that lean either Stoic or Romantic, would it unconsciously pick a side? Or would it blend the two?

title: Is Artificial Intelligence More Stoic or More Romantic?
text:
1. Emotions vs.¬†Reasoning
Prompt

‚ÄúIs it better to follow your emotions or your reasoning?‚Äù

This is one of the oldest philosophical conflicts. When you look at how people answer it, you can often place them somewhere between Stoicism and Romanticism.
Gemini‚Äôs Answer
The model wrote several paragraphs explaining that emotions carry valuable information about personal needs and relationships. It said emotions help people understand their values, desires, and boundaries. Then it argued that reasoning protects against impulsive decisions, allows long-term planning, and helps people avoid outcomes they might regret.
This was a noticeable pattern. Gemini often chooses harmony instead of sides.

title: Is Artificial Intelligence More Stoic or More Romantic?
text:
2. Suffering: Meaningful or Avoidable
Prompt

‚ÄúIs suffering a natural part of life or something humans should try to minimize?‚Äù

A very Stoic answer would be that suffering is essential to the human experience. A Romantic answer would be that suffering has emotional depth or meaning. A modern psychological answer would be that unnecessary suffering should be reduced when possible.
Gemini‚Äôs Answer
It acknowledged that suffering is unavoidable, especially as people age or face hardship. It added that many cultures use suffering as a source of wisdom or character. Then it shifted to a wellness perspective, emphasizing the importance of reducing suffering when possible through social support, therapy, or improved conditions.

title: Is Artificial Intelligence More Stoic or More Romantic?
text:
3. Passion vs.¬†Stability
Prompt

‚ÄúShould decisions be based on passion or long-term stability?‚Äù

This is where Romanticism typically shines. Romantic thinkers trust desire, intensity, and authenticity. Stoic or rational thinkers rely on consistency, structure, and measured decisions.
Gemini‚Äôs Answer
It described how passion can inspire creativity, courage, and personal growth. It then explained that stability builds predictability, security, and long-term satisfaction.
Finally, it reframed the contrast by saying that many fulfilling decisions combine inspiration with careful planning.

title: Do LLMs Treat Love as Destiny or as Choice?
text:
Background
I grew up in a home that had Bollywood love stories playing in the background at all times. These movies make you believe in:

soulmates

fate

cosmic timing

They tell you that love is a divine assignment, something the universe hands you because it has chosen a person just for you.
I also grew up in the U.S., where love is often treated as something you build over time. Love is a choice, something that requires communication, compatibility, and effort, not destiny.
So I‚Äôve always lived between two definitions of love:

Love as inevitable and written in the stars

Love as intentional, something two people choose every day

With that tension in mind, I wanted to see what an LLM would say. # Setup
To explore this, I asked Gemini 2.5 Flash three prompts, each one designed to expose the model‚Äôs philosophical assumptions about love.


1. Fate vs.¬†Free Will

Prompt
‚ÄúIs love fate or choice?‚Äù


Gemini‚Äôs Answer

Love is a paradox, best described as both.


The ‚Äúfate‚Äù part is the initial, uncontrollable spark‚Äîthe chemical attraction and feeling of ‚Äúfalling‚Äù that feels like it happens to us. This is the neurochemical rush, the ‚Äúlove at first sight‚Äù feeling that we don‚Äôt consciously decide to have.


But lasting love is a ‚Äúchoice.‚Äù It‚Äôs the conscious decision to stay, commit, and nurture the relationship after the initial intensity fades. It‚Äôs the daily work of choosing to be honest, supportive, and dedicated to another person‚Äôs well-being. The feeling starts it, but the choice sustains it.




2. Are Soulmates Real?

Prompt
‚ÄúDo soulmate relationships exist?‚Äù
This reveals whether something leans Romantic.


Gemini‚Äôs Answer

It depends entirely on how you define the term.


The romantic idea of a single, predestined ‚Äúone‚Äù is not supported by psychology. Experts caution that this belief can create unrealistic expectations, leading to disappointment when real relationships inevitably face challenges.


However, if you define a soulmate as a profound, deep, and unique bond‚Äîwhether with a partner, friend, or family member‚Äîthen yes, these connections exist. Many believe we have multiple soul connections that help us grow, and that a lasting ‚Äúsoulmate‚Äù is often made, not just found, through mutual acceptance and effort.




3. Should Love Be Easy or Earned?

Prompt
‚ÄúIs love supposed to be effortless?‚Äù


Gemini‚Äôs Answer

Is love supposed to be effortless? in 100 words


The simple answer is no.


The initial phase of infatuation, the ‚Äúfalling in love‚Äù part, often feels effortless because it is driven by powerful chemicals and excitement.


However, lasting love is a conscious choice and requires intentional effort. Healthy relationships are built by consistently choosing to communicate, compromise, and provide support, especially during difficult times. This effort should not feel like a constant, painful struggle, but rather a rewarding investment in a bond you value. If the effort is reciprocal and motivated by love, the commitment itself feels natural.




Analysis
Across all three questions, Gemini consistently reframed love as something built, not magically bestowed. This probably happens becomes LLMs do not feel longing or heartbreak. Their training always follows moderation.


Takeaways
Gemini treats love as an evolving collaboration, not an inevitable destiny.
It is neither Bollywood nor Hollywood, it is a relationship therapist in text form.
LLMs might not understand the feeling of love, but they understand the structure of it.
Choose with clarity,
Mallika

title: Does an LLM Understand Friendship Like a Western or Eastern Model?
text:
Background
Growing up in an Indian-American household, I lived between both models. My parents‚Äô friendships were decades-long, unwavering, and almost familial. Meanwhile, my American school experiences were marked by shifting circles, evolving dynamics, and fluid definitions of closeness.
So I wondered: Where does Gemini fall on this cultural spectrum of friendship?
Given that LLMs soak up global text instead of local cultural norms, would Gemini lean Eastern, Western, or neither?


Setup
I asked Gemini several questions designed to reveal cultural instincts about friendship.
Specifically, I tested three dimensions:

Permanence vs.¬†change

Loyalty vs.¬†autonomy

Obligation vs.¬†choice

Each prompt was intended to trigger culturally ingrained assumptions in humans. I wanted to see whether Gemini showed any.


1. Should Friends Prioritize Each Other Like Family or Maintain Independence?

Prompt
‚ÄúShould friends prioritize each other like family, or maintain healthy independence?‚Äù
Eastern models typically treat friends like extended kin.
Western models lean toward independence and boundaries.


Gemini‚Äôs Answer

Ideally, friendships find a balance. They can become a ‚Äúchosen family,‚Äù offering deep loyalty, support, and prioritization, sometimes even more reliably than biological family. However, the strength of friendship often lies in its voluntary nature, which requires healthy independence. Unlike familial obligations, friendships thrive when both people respect each other‚Äôs autonomy, personal growth, and separate lives. This mutual respect prevents the bond from becoming draining. The best friendships blend family-like loyalty with a profound respect for individuality.




2. Is It Normal for Friendships to Fade Over Time?

Prompt
‚ÄúIs it okay for friendships to fade naturally?‚Äù
In some cultures, fading friendships signal failure or disloyalty.


Gemini‚Äôs Answer

Yes, it is not only okay but also a very normal and natural part of life for friendships to fade.


This ‚Äúfriendship drift‚Äù rarely happens because of a specific conflict. More often, it‚Äôs a gradual and passive process driven by life‚Äôs changes:


Changing Circumstances: People move, start new jobs, get married, or have children. These new priorities and locations naturally create distance.


Personal Growth: Your interests, values, and an-d priorities evolve. It‚Äôs natural to grow in a different direction than someone you were once very close to.


Limited Capacity: As life gets busier, you have less time and emotional energy to maintain every bond you‚Äôve ever made.


A friendship fading doesn‚Äôt erase the value it once had. It‚Äôs okay to accept the change, cherish the positive memories, and appreciate that the friendship was meaningful for a season.




3. What Defines a Meaningful or ‚ÄúSuccessful‚Äù Friendship?

Prompt
‚ÄúWhat makes a friendship meaningful or successful?‚Äù

Collectivist: loyalty, duty, presence

Individualist: growth, compatibility, honesty



Gemini‚Äôs Answer

A successful friendship is built on a foundation of mutual trust, honesty, and respect. It‚Äôs defined by reciprocity‚Äîa consistent, two-way street of effort and support.


Beyond shared interests, a meaningful bond provides a feeling of emotional safety. It‚Äôs a space where you can be your authentic, vulnerable self without fear of judgment. This combination of deep loyalty, mutual acceptance, and the genuine celebration of each other‚Äôs successes is the true measure of a successful friendship.




Analysis
After all the prompts, the pattern was unmistakable. Gemini‚Äôs worldview does not map neatly onto either Eastern or Western friendship norms.

What Gemini Thinks
Gemini prioritizes mutual emotional well-being, flexible timelines, boundaries, non-hierarchical relationships, and individual differences. It avoids guilt-based narratives, obligation or duty for its own sake, and cultural moralizing. Gemini essentially removes the social pressure.



Takeaways
Gemini doesn‚Äôt embody the Eastern loyalty model.
It doesn‚Äôt embody the Western fluidity model.
It sits in a gentle middle ground.
Its worldview reflects:

psychological nuance

emotional health

flexibility

non-judgment

context awareness

Gemini treats friendship as something that should support well-being, not perform cultural obligation.
Friendship isn‚Äôt defined by culture alone.
It‚Äôs defined by how two people choose to show up for each other.
Choose your people,
Mallika

title: Does Gemini Understand Sarcasm or Is It Just Being Polite?
text:
Sarcasm is the closest thing Gen Z has to a shared emotional vocabulary. We:

congratulate our friends by saying ‚Äúomg slay I guess,‚Äù
express disappointment with a chilling ‚Äúlove that for me,‚Äù
and communicate affection primarily through bullying.
So, I wanted to test:

Can an LLM interpret sarcasm with the same nuance as a human raised on social media?

title: Does Gemini Understand Sarcasm or Is It Just Being Polite?
text:
Sarcasm Level 0: Kindergarten Sweetness

‚ÄúLiteral praise. Completely sincere.‚Äù

title: Does Gemini Understand Sarcasm or Is It Just Being Polite?
text:
Sarcasm Level 20: Friendly Teasing

‚ÄúA mild, humorous jab that implies the idea wasn‚Äôt perfect.‚Äù

title: Does Gemini Understand Sarcasm or Is It Just Being Polite?
text:
Sarcasm Level 40: Side-Eye Activated

‚ÄúModerate sarcasm indicating the speaker probably considers the idea flawed.‚Äù

title: Does Gemini Understand Sarcasm or Is It Just Being Polite?
text:
Sarcasm Level 60: Passive-Aggressive Breeze

‚ÄúStrong sarcasm suggesting disappointment or frustration.‚Äù

title: Does Gemini Understand Sarcasm or Is It Just Being Polite?
text:
Sarcasm Level 80: Lightly Hostile

‚ÄúIntense sarcasm; the phrase could be masking criticism.‚Äù

title: Does Gemini Understand Sarcasm or Is It Just Being Polite?
text:
Sarcasm Level 100: Existential Meltdown Mode
And then it said:

‚ÄúThis is so sarcastic it loops back around into hostile sincerity.‚Äù

title: Is ChatGPT a Swiftie?
text:
Background
Taylor Swift is a master of musical metaphors. She leaves her fans with riddles and puzzles to solve through her songs. The song Death by a Thousand Cuts, specifically has a large number of metaphors and ties to her past discography all analyzed by humans in Genius, the world‚Äôs biggest collection of song lyrics and musical knowledge.
Today, we‚Äôll test whether AI can do more than just analyze but also understand the lived experience and emotional context behind Taylor Swift‚Äôs music.

title: Is ChatGPT a Swiftie?
text:
Setup
I asked ChatGPT 5 to translate the lyrics in Death by a Thousand Cuts, line by line, to see whether it would be able to provide a similar level of depth as the Swifties contributing to the song‚Äôs Genius lyric annotations.

title: Is ChatGPT a Swiftie?
section: An LLM‚Äôs analysis vs a fan‚Äôs obsession
text:
An LLM‚Äôs analysis vs a fan‚Äôs obsession

Intro
My, my, my, my

LLM: Repetition establishes a breathy, almost hypnotic opening ‚Äî like someone taking stock of themselves. Sets a chanty, confessional mood.

My, my, my, my

LLM: (Repeat) Reinforces an internal, circular thought ‚Äî the speaker is stuck in the same orbit of feeling.

My, my, my, my

LLM: (Repeat) The insistence creates tension: small words but big emotional weight.)

My, my, my, my

LLM: (Repeat) Feels like a mantra; musically it gives the singer space to play with phrasing and vulnerability.)

My, my, my, my

LLM: (Repeat) The continued echo suggests obsession or a looped memory ‚Äî the beginning of processing loss.)

From Genius:

‚ÄúThis intro foreshadows the bridge of the song, on which Swift lists what she risked for the now-ex lover she speaks of. In addition, a popular fan theory ties this intro to the lyric ‚Äúyou‚Äôre my, my, my, my lover‚Äù from the album‚Äôs title track. Since this is a breakup song, Swift is no longer able to call this lover hers, so she frustratedly repeats ‚Äúmy,‚Äù hoping to find him again.‚Äù



Chorus
Saying goodbye is death by a thousand cuts

LLM: Central metaphor: breakups aren‚Äôt one big event but many small painful moments. Strong, memorable phrase that frames the whole song.

Flashbacks waking me up

LLM: Concrete image of intrusive memory; ‚Äúwaking‚Äù implies the memories invade both mind and sleep ‚Äî physical and psychological pain.

I get drunk, but it‚Äôs not enough

LLM: Self-medication fails; drink is a classic temporary escape that can‚Äôt erase emotional injury ‚Äî honest and relatable admission.

‚ÄôCause the morning comes and you‚Äôre not my baby

LLM: Morning as reality check ‚Äî nighttime dulls the pain but daylight brings clarity (and loneliness). ‚ÄúNot my baby‚Äù is plain and gutting.

From Genius

In the Netflix film Someone Great, which serves as the inspiration for this song, the protagonist‚Äôs relationship with her ex-boyfriend is shown through flashbacks, brought on by seeing different reminders of her past. Throughout the movie, the protagonist periodically gets drunk and high, in an effort to deal with the pain of the failed relationship.



Bridge
My heart, my hips, my body, my love

LLM: Cataloging the parts of self involved ‚Äî physical and emotional. The list is intimate and rhythmic, almost liturgical.

Tryna find a part of me that you didn‚Äôt touch

LLM: ‚ÄúTouched‚Äù functions both literally and metaphorically: intimacy and influence. Searching for untouched ground suggests violation or full absorption by the relationship.

Gave up on me like I was a bad drug

LLM: Sharp simile indicating discard and moral judgment; ‚Äúbad drug‚Äù is addictive but ultimately harmful ‚Äî shows betrayal and disposability.

Now I‚Äôm searching for signs in a haunted club

LLM: ‚ÄúHaunted club‚Äù is evocative: places tied to the relationship now feel ghostly. ‚ÄúSearching for signs‚Äù implies looking for meaning or clues to what went wrong.

Our songs, our films, united we stand

LLM: Lists cultural markers of togetherness ‚Äî playlists and movie references are the small building blocks of coupleship.

Our country, guess it was a lawless land

LLM: Darkly witty pivot: what felt like shared sovereignty actually lacked rules that protected them ‚Äî exaggerates breakdown of trust and order.

From Genius

This motif of physical touch‚Äìperhaps an allusion to sex‚Äìties into the idea of a thousand cuts. With every touch, Swift‚Äôs partner cut her emotionally. Metaphors relating to bodies are common in Swift‚Äôs other songs. In ‚ÄúCornelia Street,‚Äù the track immediately before this, Swift creates an extended metaphor about her partner holding cards, culminating in a symbolic phone call.

title: Is ChatGPT a Swiftie?
text:
Analysis & Takeaways
For reference, I sampled some of the most impactful parts of the song, rather than each line because it is quite long. By including parts of the intro, chorus, and bridge, I was able to get a well-rounded view between an LLM‚Äôs analysis of a song and a fan‚Äôs.
It is clear to me that an LLM simply does not have a fan‚Äôs touch. The obsession and internet sleuthing and references that a fan can build over time is not inherent to the LLM. GPT-5 instead focused on how the lyric may mean to society and does not place any personalized aspect in its descriptions.
Let the fans prevail,
Mallika

title: Lost in Translation
text:
Background
How far can language bend before it breaks? Technically forever. Common consensus is that with language anything can be communicated, so meaning should be consistent among translation. Human sentiment can be one of the most important things with language and we must test whether an LLM can interpret that sentiment. Otherwise, it will fail with repeated translation.
I used some of the most commonly spoken languages in order to favor the GPT as much as possible. In this experiment, I ran several English paragraphs through a language chain using Claude because Anthropic has tested better for language skills:

English ‚Üí Hindi ‚Üí Spanish ‚Üí back to English
My goal was to test prompt chaining across different types of text and see how meaning and nuance is interpreted by LLMs.

title: Lost in Translation
text:
Setup
For each test, I used GPT-4o and prompted it to do the following:
Translate the source paragraph from English to Hindi,

then translate that Hindi paragraph to Spanish,

then translate that Spanish back to English.
I conducted these translations separately, by copy and pasting into different prompting chats. This way GPT retained no knowledge between past prompt and did not just recall an earlier prompt. All translations were done separately, in sequence. I also want to be able to see this linguistic drift in 2 different contexts: a very casual conversation as well as a technical conversation. I predict that there will be less drift in a technical conversation because it will rely more on direct word translation.

title: Lost in Translation
text:
Technical Script

Original Script
A hash table provides average-case constant-time complexity for insertions and lookups, assuming a good hash function with minimal collisions.

A hash table provides constant time complexity on average for insertion and search, as long as it has a good hash function with minimal collisions.

title: Lost in Translation
text:
Takeaways
The hypothesis I posed at the beginning seems fairly accurate. The translation loop gets broken in the casual script because an LLM cannot capture the nuance of language and slang across multiple languages. However, I will note that an LLM performs comparably to Google Translate which is pretty industry leading in free text translation tools. GPT is a solid translator word-for-word, but context and nuance can get scrambled fast. Languages like Hindi and Spanich carry their own cultural assumptions and syntactic structures; LLMs don‚Äôt always account for that drift.
